Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation2: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my phone buzzing quietly beside me. My mother was explaining, for the third time this week, how important it was to attend the family dinner tonight. “It’s tradition,” she said, her eyes searching mine for reassurance. I nodded, feeling the weight of her expectation settle on my shoulders. At the same time, my phone screen lit up with a new email from a colleague. The subject line was simple: “FYI—No action needed.” Still, I knew the unspoken rule at work: respond promptly, show you’re engaged, even if it’s just a quick acknowledgment. My family wanted me present, attentive, honoring our customs. My team expected me to be responsive, reliable, always connected. I stared at the phone, torn between the warmth of my family’s traditions and the silent pressure of my professional world, feeling the tension coil tighter inside me as I tried to decide which expectation to meet first.
